column1: The name for Japan in Japanese is written using the kanji 日本 and pronounced Nippon or Nihon. Before it was adopted in the early 8th century

column1: Japan is a unitary state and constitutional monarchy in which the power of the Emperor is limited to a ceremonial role. He is defined in the Constitution as "the symbol of the state and of the unity of the people". Executive power is instead wielded by the Prime Minister of Japan and his Cabinet
column2: whose sovereignty is vested in the Japanese people. Naruhito is the current Emperor of Japan

column1: Japan's legislative organ is the National Diet

It is a participant in the International Space Station: the Japanese Experiment Module (Kibō) was added to the station during Space Shuttle assembly flights in 2008. The space probe Akatsuki was launched in 2010 and achieved orbit around Venus in 2015. Japan's plans in space exploration include building a moon base by 2030. In 2007
column32: it launched lunar explorer SELENE (Selenological and Engineering Explorer) from Tanegashima Space Center. The largest lunar mission since the Apollo program
column33: its purpose was to gather data on the moon's origin and evolution. It entered a lunar orbit on October 4

column2: 39% of energy in Japan was produced from petroleum
column3: 25% from coal

column5: 3.5% from hydropower and 1.5% from nuclear power. Nuclear power was down from 11.2 percent in 2010. By May 2012 all of the country's nuclear power plants had been taken offline because of ongoing public opposition following the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster in March 2011
column6: though government officials continued to try to sway public opinion in favor of returning at least some to service. The Sendai Nuclear Power Plant restarted in 2015
column7: and since then several other nuclear power plants have been restarted. Japan lacks significant domestic reserves and so has a heavy dependence on imported energy. Japan has therefore aimed to diversify its sources and maintain high levels of energy efficiency.

column1: The government took responsibility for regulating the water and sanitation sector is shared between the Ministry of Health

Access to an improved water source is universal in Japan. 97% of the population receives piped water supply from public utilities and 3% receive water from their own wells or unregulated small systems
column5: mainly in rural areas.

column1: Japan has a population of 126.3 million

column22: the largest community of Westerners.Japan has the second longest overall life expectancy at birth of any country in the world: 83.5 years for persons born in the period 2010–2015. The Japanese population is rapidly aging as a result of a post–World War II baby boom followed by a decrease in birth rates. In 2012
column23: about 24.1 percent of the population was over 65
column24: and the proportion is projected to rise to almost 40 percent by 2050. On September 15
column27: one in five Japanese residents was aged 70 or older. 26.18 million people are 70 or older and accounted for 20.7 percent of the population. Elderly women crossed the 20 million line at 20.12 million
column28: substantially outnumbering the nation's 15.45 million elderly men. The changes in demographic structure have created a number of social issues
column29: particularly a potential decline in workforce population and increase in the cost of social security benefits. A growing number of younger Japanese are not marrying or remain childless. Japan's population is expected to drop to 95 million by 2050.Immigration and birth incentives are sometimes suggested as a solution to provide younger workers to support the nation's aging population. Japan accepts an average flow of 9
column30: 500 new naturalized citizens per year. On April 1
column32: Japan's revised immigration law was enacted
column33: protecting the rights of foreign workers to help reduce labor shortages in certain sectors.

column1: Japan's constitution guarantees full religious freedom. Upper estimates suggest that 84–96 percent of the Japanese population subscribe to Shinto as its indigenous religion (50% to 80% of which considering degrees of syncretism with Buddhism
column2: shinbutsu-shūgō). However
column3: these estimates are based on people affiliated with a temple
column4: rather than the number of true believers. Many Japanese people practice both Shinto and Buddhism; they can either identify with both religions or describe themselves as non-religious or spiritual
column5: despite participating in religious ceremonies as a cultural tradition. As a result
column6: religious statistics are often under-reported in Japan. Other studies have suggested that only 30 percent of the population identify themselves as belonging to a religion. Nevertheless
column7: the level of participation remains high
column8: especially during festivals and occasions such as the first shrine visit of the New Year. Taoism and Confucianism from China have also influenced Japanese beliefs and customs.Christianity was first introduced into Japan by Jesuit missions starting in 1549. Today
column9: fewer than 1% to 2.3% are Christians
column10: most of them living in the western part of the country.  As of 2007
column11: there were 32
column12: 036 Christian priests and pastors in Japan. Throughout the latest century
column13: some Western customs originally related to Christianity (including Western style weddings
column14: Valentine's Day and Christmas) have become popular as secular customs among many Japanese.Islam in Japan is estimated to constitute about 80–90% of foreign-born migrants and their children
column15: primarily from Indonesia
column16: Pakistan
column17: Bangladesh
column18: and Iran. Many of the ethnic Japanese Muslims are those who convert upon marrying immigrant Muslims. The Pew Research Center estimated that there were 185
column19: 000 Muslims in Japan in 2010.Other minority religions include Hinduism
column23: and Baháʼí Faith; since the mid-19th century numerous new religious movements have emerged in Japan.

column1: More than 99 percent of the population speaks Japanese as their first language. Japanese writing uses kanji (Chinese characters) and two sets of kana (syllabaries based on cursive script and radical of kanji)
column2: as well as the Latin alphabet and Arabic numerals. Public and private schools generally require students to take Japanese language classes as well as English language courses.Besides Japanese
column3: the Ryukyuan languages (Amami
column4: Kunigami
column5: Okinawan
column7: Yaeyama
column8: Yonaguni)
column9: also part of the Japonic language family

column12: which is a language isolate
column14: with only a few elderly native speakers remaining in Hokkaido.

column2: secondary schools and universities were introduced in 1872 as a result of the Meiji Restoration. Since 1947
column3: compulsory education in Japan comprises elementary and junior high school
column4: which together last for nine years (from age 6 to age 15). Almost all children continue their education at a three-year senior high school. The two top-ranking universities in Japan are the University of Tokyo and Kyoto University. Japan's education system played a central part in the country's recovery after World War II when the Fundamental Law of Education and the School Education Law were enacted. The latter law defined the standard school system. Starting in April 2016
column5: various schools began the academic year with elementary school and junior high school integrated into one nine-year compulsory schooling program; MEXT plans for this approach to be adopted nationwide.The Programme for International Student Assessment coordinated by the OECD currently ranks the overall knowledge and skills of Japanese 15-year-olds as the third best in the world. Japan is one of the top-performing OECD countries in reading literacy
column6: math and sciences with the average student scoring 529 and has one of the world's highest-educated labor forces among OECD countries. In 2015
column7: Japan's public spending on education amounted to just 4.1 percent of its GDP
column8: below the OECD average of 5.0 percent. The country's large pool of highly educated and skilled individuals is largely responsible for ushering Japan's post-war economic growth.  In 2017
column9: the country ranked third for the percentage of 25 to 64 year-olds that have attained tertiary education with 51 percent. In addition
column10: 60.4 percent Japanese aged 25 to 34 have some form of tertiary education qualification and bachelor's degrees are held by 30.4 percent of Japanese aged 25 to 64
column11: the second most in the OECD after South Korea.

column1: Health care is provided by national and local governments. Payment for personal medical services is offered through a universal health insurance system that provides relative equality of access
column2: with fees set by a government committee. People without insurance through employers can participate in a national health insurance program administered by local governments. Since 1973
column3: all elderly persons have been covered by government-sponsored insurance. Japan has a high suicide rate; suicide is the leading cause of death for people under 30. Another significant public health issue is smoking. Japan has the lowest rate of heart disease in the OECD
column4: and the lowest level of dementia in the developed world.

column2: largely of wood
column3: and Japanese painting are among the oldest of the Japanese arts
column4: with early figurative paintings dating to at least 300 BC. The history of Japanese painting exhibits synthesis and competition between native Japanese esthetics and imported ideas. The interaction between Japanese and European art has been significant: for example ukiyo-e prints
column5: which began to be exported in the 19th century in the movement known as Japonism
column6: had a significant influence on the development of modern art in the West
column7: most notably on post-Impressionism. Japanese manga developed in the 20th century and have become popular worldwide.Japanese architecture is a combination between local and other influences. It has traditionally been typified by wooden structures
column8: elevated slightly off the ground
column9: with tiled or thatched roofs. The Shrines of Ise have been celebrated as the prototype of Japanese architecture. Largely of wood

column12: Japan has incorporated much of Western

column15: it was not until after World War II that Japanese architects made an impression on the international scene
column16: firstly with the work of architects like Kenzō Tange and then with movements like Metabolism.

column1: The earliest works of Japanese literature include the Kojiki and Nihon Shoki chronicles and the Man'yōshū poetry anthology
column2: all from the 8th century and written in Chinese characters. In the early Heian period
column3: the system of phonograms known as kana (hiragana and katakana) was developed. The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter is considered the oldest Japanese narrative. An account of court life is given in The Pillow Book by Sei Shōnagon
column4: while The Tale of Genji by Murasaki Shikibu is often described as the world's first novel.During the Edo period
column5: the chōnin ("townspeople") overtook the samurai aristocracy as producers and consumers of literature. The popularity of the works of Saikaku
column7: reveals this change in readership and authorship
column8: while Bashō revivified the poetic tradition of the Kokinshū with his haikai (haiku) and wrote the poetic travelogue Oku no Hosomichi. The Meiji era saw the decline of traditional literary forms as Japanese literature integrated Western influences. Natsume Sōseki and Mori Ōgai were the first "modern" novelists of Japan
column9: followed by Ryūnosuke Akutagawa
column10: Jun'ichirō Tanizaki
column11: Yukio Mishima and
column12: more recently
column13: Haruki Murakami. Japan has two Nobel Prize-winning authors – Yasunari Kawabata (1968) and Kenzaburō Ōe (1994).Japanese philosophy has historically been a fusion of both foreign
column15: and uniquely Japanese elements. In its literary forms
column16: Japanese philosophy began about fourteen centuries ago. Confucian ideals are still evident today in the Japanese concept of society and the self
column17: and in the organization of the government and the structure of society. Buddhism has profoundly impacted Japanese psychology

column1: Japanese music is eclectic and diverse. Many instruments
column2: such as the koto

column4: with the guitar-like shamisen

Notable classical composers from Japan include Toru Takemitsu and Rentarō Taki. Popular music in post-war Japan has been heavily influenced by American and European trends
column8: which has led to the evolution of J-pop. Karaoke is the most widely practiced cultural activity in Japan.The four traditional theaters from Japan are noh

column1: Ishin-denshin (以心伝心) is a Japanese idiom which denotes a form of interpersonal communication through unspoken mutual understanding. Isagiyosa (潔さ) is a virtue of the capability of accepting death with composure. Cherry blossoms are a symbol of isagiyosa in the sense of embracing the transience of the world. Hansei (反省) is a central idea in Japanese culture
column2: meaning to acknowledge one's own mistake and to pledge improvement. Kotodama (言霊) refers to the Japanese belief that mystical powers dwell in words and names. There are many annual festivals in Japan
column3: which are called in Japanese matsuri (祭). There are no specific festival days for all of Japan; dates vary from area to area
column4: and even within a specific area
column5: but festival days do tend to cluster around traditional holidays such as Setsubun or Obon.

column2: Japan has 16 national
column3: government-recognized holidays. Public holidays in Japan are regulated by the Public Holiday Law (国民の祝日に関する法律
column4: Kokumin no Shukujitsu ni Kansuru Hōritsu) of 1948. Beginning in 2000
column5: Japan implemented the Happy Monday System
column6: which moved a number of national holidays to Monday in order to obtain a long weekend. The national holidays in Japan are New Year's Day on January 1
column7: Coming of Age Day on Second Monday of January
column8: National Foundation Day on February 11
column9: The Emperor's Birthday on February 23
column10: Vernal Equinox Day on March 20 or 21
column11: Shōwa Day on April 29
column12: Constitution Memorial Day on May 3
column15: Marine Day on Third Monday of July
column16: Mountain Day on August 11
column17: Respect for the Aged Day on Third Monday of September
column19: Health and Sports Day on Second Monday of October
column21: and Labor Thanksgiving Day on November 23.

column1: Japanese cuisine is known for its emphasis on seasonality of food
column2: quality of ingredients and presentation. Japanese cuisine offers a vast array of regional specialties that use traditional recipes and local ingredients. Seafood and Japanese rice or noodles are traditional staple of Japanese cuisine
column3: typically seasoned with a combination of dashi
column4: soy sauce
column5: mirin
column7: sugar
column8: and salt. Dishes inspired by foreign food—in particular Chinese food—like ramen and gyōza
column9: as well as foods like spaghetti
column10: curry
column11: and hamburgers have become adopted with variants for Japanese tastes and ingredients. Japanese curry
column12: since its introduction to Japan from British India
column13: is so widely consumed that it can be called a national dish. Traditional Japanese sweets are known as wagashi. Ingredients such as red bean paste and mochi are used. More modern-day tastes includes green tea ice cream.Popular Japanese beverages include sake
column14: which is a brewed rice beverage that typically contains 14–17% alcohol and is made by multiple fermentation of rice. Beer has been brewed in Japan since the late 17th century. Green tea is produced in Japan and prepared in various forms such as matcha
column15: used in the Japanese tea ceremony.

column1: Television and newspapers take an important role in Japanese mass media
column2: though radio and magazines also take a part. Over the 1990s
column3: television surpassed newspapers as Japan's main information and entertainment medium. There are six nationwide television networks: NHK (public broadcasting)
column4: Nippon Television (NTV)
column5: Tokyo Broadcasting System (TBS)
column7: TV Asahi (EX) and TV Tokyo Network (TXN). Television networks were mostly established based on capital investments by existing radio networks. Variety shows
column8: serial dramas
column9: and news constitute a large percentage of Japanese television shows. According to the 2015 NHK survey on television viewing in Japan
column10: 79 percent of Japanese watch television daily.Japanese readers have a choice of approximately 120 daily newspapers
column11: with an average subscription rate of 1.13 newspapers per household. The main newspapers are the Yomiuri Shimbun
column12: Asahi Shimbun
column14: Nikkei Shimbun and Sankei Shimbun. According to a survey conducted by the Japanese Newspaper Association in 1999
column15: 85.4 percent of men and 75 percent of women read a newspaper every day.Japan has one of the oldest and largest film industries in the world; movies have been produced in Japan since 1897. Ishirō Honda's Godzilla became an international icon of Japan and spawned an entire subgenre of kaiju films
column16: as well as the longest-running film franchise in history. Japan has won the Academy Award for the Best Foreign Language Film four times
column17: more than any other Asian country. Japanese animated films and television series
column19: were largely influenced by Japanese manga and have been extensively popular in the West. Japan is a world-renowned powerhouse of animation.

column2: sumo is considered Japan's national sport. Japanese martial arts such as judo
column3: karate and kendo are also widely practiced and enjoyed by spectators in the country. After the Meiji Restoration
column4: many Western sports were introduced. Baseball is currently the most popular spectator sport in the country. Japan's top professional league
column5: now known as Nippon Professional Baseball
column6: was established in 1936 and is widely considered to be the highest level of professional baseball in the world outside of the North American Major Leagues. Since the establishment of the Japan Professional Football League in 1992
column7: association football has also gained a wide following. Japan was a venue of the Intercontinental Cup from 1981 to 2004 and co-hosted the 2002 FIFA World Cup with South Korea. Japan has one of the most successful football teams in Asia
column8: winning the Asian Cup four times
column9: and the FIFA Women's World Cup in 2011. Golf is also popular in Japan.Japan has significant involvement in motorsport. Japanese automotive manufacturers have been successful in multiple different categories
column10: with titles and victories in series such as Formula One
column11: MotoGP
column12: IndyCar
column15: World Touring Car Championship
column16: British Touring Car Championship and the IMSA SportsCar Championship. Three Japanese drivers have achieved podium finishes in Formula One
column17: and drivers from Japan also have victories at the Indianapolis 500 and the 24 Hours of Le Mans
column18: in addition to success in domestic championships. Super GT is the most popular national series in Japan
column19: while Super Formula is the top level domestic open-wheel series. The country also hosts major races such as the Japanese Grand Prix
column23: FIA WTCC Race of Japan and the Indy Japan 300.

column1: Japan hosted the Summer Olympics in Tokyo in 1964 and the Winter Olympics in Sapporo in 1972 and Nagano in 1998. Further

column4: more than any other nation. Japan is the most successful Asian Rugby Union country
column5: winning the Asian Five Nations a record six times and winning the newly formed IRB Pacific Nations Cup in 2011. Japan also hosted the 2019 IRB Rugby World Cup.
